My daughter wanted me to make her a crown. She wanted me to make her a sparkly crown. I looked at RichRap's Sparkle Printing process, but don't have any clear PLA as I mostly use ABS. I also wasn't really keen on the idea of intentionally sprinkling contamination into my printer enclosure. Then I got to thinking about how sticky the parts are when they just come out of vapor polishing... and sparkle polishing was born. I consider this to be primarily a derivative of the RichRap thing:14912, but the source file is the crown from thing:66757.

NOTE: Still working on how to do this. This is actually the first time in my life that I can recall picking up a container of sparkles. Any suggestions from people with crafting experience are welcome. 1) Print something in ABS.
2) Vapor Polish
3) Remove from polishing bath
4) Shake on sparkles. This should be done when the surface is still almost liquidy. Alternatively, you could probably roll or dip into a bucket of sparkles. Or maybe put it into a bag and shake it around?
5) Allow solvent to fully evaporate.
6) Present thing to your favorite princess.
7) Bask in the glow of being the coolest dad or {insert whatever your relationship is here}.

comments.text:

Have fun!

description.text:
'Stik Men' is a set of 3D printed Stick figures in different poses. They are quick and easy prints. Separate .stl files have been provided for each Stick Man so you can print one, two or as many as you like. The full line up is 12 'Stik Men'.   
If you print some post your pictures showing what they're doing!   
Well printed 'Stik Men' should stand well on their own two feet as they are angled slightly forward on their feet. At standard size they stand approx. 6cm tall but should be able to be scaled up easily if you want them bigger.   
Use 'Stick Men' around the house for reminders and as decorative fun features. Refer to the images to see what 'Stik Men' are already doing... great fun little prints to have around!  
'Stik Men' should print easily on any machine in a few minutes. They use very little filament. I recommend using Raft for ease of removal from the build plate (particularly if you are printing quite a few)  
Refer to the instructions tab for print recommendations.  
Note: If you like these designs check out all my other listings.

Very easy prints that use very little filament but need to be printed with a lot of infill to ensure they are strong enough not to be damaged when removing them from the build plate or raft. Recommend settings: Raft On
.020mm Resolution
2 Shells
75% infill
No Support Work great with PLA but other filament should be fine as well. Will scale up easily if desired. Standard size is approx. 6cm tall when stood on their feet.

I took the original file (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:295531) and changed multiple things to make it fit. I printed 2 of these at the meeting, and they both worked! The "forks" (the part that breaks off and causes this mess) needed to be widened to go around the peg in the controller, and they needed to be positioned a little bit lower to properly fit it in the slot. I also widened the side slots a bit because it took pressure to fit the cover down onto those little guide rails Someone at the NMRA meeting also mentioned that the raised letters interfered with the battery when they tried this model, so I made the lettering recessed instead. (And yes, I left the logo alone. ASMR created 99% of this file, I just tweaked 3 or 4 dimensions to make it work. Hat tip.) I'm sure that a few more refinements would make this an even better fit, but it just needed to work. Please tweak and modify to your heart's content.

I had some outdoor furniture that broke a wheel.   I created this model to replace the wheel that was on it.  The wheel is 4-inches in diameter and 1-inch thick at the rim with an inner axle thickness of 1.25-inches.  
The actual printed object is only 1/2 of a wheel.  You will print 2 and join them together with some epoxy or glue.   This makes the object easier to print.   
You may need to rotate the object for your slicer so that it lays flat on the bed.
Created using FreeCAD.  Sized to fit my existing wheel.  The design is my original work.

Here's another remix, with a screw-on cap. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1036486 On this one, a cover protects the wheel's exposed face. My main concern was the lid wouldn't fit correctly, so I printed two sets. The lid is a perfect snap-fit on both. The center hole is slightly tapered, smaller on the bottom end, so (theoretically) just 3 points touch the mandrel, minimizing friction. If the fit is uncomfortably snug, I'd recommend forcing the mandrel all the way through the hole, thus enlarging it a bit. If too loose, scale both the lid and body down by the same amount. Perhaps 1% (or less) will be satisfactory. Seems safest to get it started, and pull the shank end through until the wheel seats, rather than push on the wheel end. On an Afinia, I used 0.30mm layers and slow speed (fine quality) plus fan cooling. A set took 27 minutes, and used 10g ABS. Metric and SAE files provided.

Prototype sleeve for Voss 375mL bottle. The sleeve is a very basic cylinder created in Blender. Exterior diameter is 58.0mm, interior diameter is 57.5mm. The sleeve fits tightly around bottle. Sleeve is 150m in length, and is printed vertically for maximum build quality. If you have a printer with a larger z-axis, you can resize to 180mm. If not, you can modify the design and create another 3cm cylinder. Software tools: Blender, Makerbot Desktop.
Printer: Flashforge Creator Pro
Filament: Hatchbox Transparent White PLA 1.75mm

Extruder temp 200 degrees C (also worked at 210)
Platform Temperature 60 degrees C
Printed fine with no raft, no support
Infill not relevant for this design. Cylinder thickness is .5mm
If using Makerbot, select "Move Item to Platform".
X3G file can be printed directly on Flashforge Creator Pro

comments.text: Noticed the math on the Info and Instruction pages conflict. Blender says the wall is 0.25mm thick. 58-57.5=0.5, and /2=0.25 thickness. My nozzle orifice is ~.5mm, so can't print anything thinner than that. But it's a new upload, and you'd catch and correct it eventually. The reason I commented is just an FYI. I have an Afinia and it can't see thicknesses less than ~0.04" thick (~1mm). Very thin sections are invisible to the software. I wouldn't know about other printers' software limitations, but nozzle orifice size seems like a universal limitation.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: Thanks.  I did not know that Blender could calculate thickness.  As for the math, I am trying to think up some lame excuse about how long it has been since I took a math class, but...  I get your point.  If the total difference in diameter is .5mm, then the difference in radius is .5mm/2 or .25mm.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: "Blender says" was a misstatement. I d/loaded the file and opened it in blender, and dragged a cube to the top edge, and shrunk it until it fit. I regularly make the same diameter / wall thickness calculation error, so it caught my attention.

description.text:
I have built a custom sliced wade's extruder (more on this later) that can develop quite some pressure. Since I do not have a lathe, I dremelled the bolt (M8x8) using the method described by Elk http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9291. This initially worked well, but I was confronted with early failure of the bolt (see picture) and I wasn't quite satisfied with the precision obtained with that method (picture), so I built this small indexer. This is to be manually rotated after each hobbing cycle.
An obvious further development would be adding a stepper (a quick release coupler, anyone?) but I'd need to care about changing the parallel port interface or configuring emc-arduino.

Lasercut or route (Used 5.85 mm plywood), assemble. Optionally epoxy but it seems already strong enough. Use:mount a dremel quick-release disk on your cnc. Distance from hob center to base plate is 20 mm. Set Y = 0 to the surface of the bolt. video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UoZG40X2cg4 Caution, use eye protection and keep your hands at a safe distance. The bolt gets quite hot, pace your work. I attached a very basic piece of gcode that pauses at each indexing stage using M60 Parting thoughts: maybe 16 hobs per revolution is too many, I should try indexing disks with 15 to 12 divisions.

comments.text: .....that looks tempting for me to make, and i've got the best hobbed bolt you can buy already. ........o'h and don't forget to scrub them bolts extra well before using them, a tiny particle of bolt will clog up your nozzle extruder!

comments.text: Its working pretty good.  I have not gotten any of the bent teeth etc.  The only thing I have noticed is that without a guide the filament tends to slide to the side past the bearing and then it stops feeding.  I really like the straight grooves for simplicity however on the next one I may file a groove first and then hob it so that the filament tracks in the groove, it would also increase the the surface to teeth connection.  All in all its working very good.  I am on my second pound of plastic and its still working.  Oh, and its easy to clean out the grooves with an exacto when it does jam and slip.  Thanks again.
comments.author: Lanthan

comments.text: What extruder are you using?
comments.author: ednspace

comments.text: Yup! you called it, its a Greg's Hinged.  There is a big block shaped hole above the bolt, lots of room for the filament to move around.  Lucky for me most of the time it rides down the outside wall where it is all safe, otherwise if it moves over to far the other way it slips off the edge of the bearing guide and jams.  I need to print a guide for a temporary fix I guess.  The extruder you pointed to looks amazizng. I'll have to check it out further.

comments.text: That extruder has proven to be a "forget it exists" thing, no troubles at all, no need to set a fan cooling it, etc. I think it is OK for any stationary extruder (a la makerbot or bowden), while for a moving carriage it is on the heavy side (but there is room for trimming down the design). Let me know if you have any questions about machining it.

author: ThingSurac

description.text:
A box for Grado 932 module
This module can be connected to a K-type thermocouple
I use it on my home made smokehouse

When you print small things or difficult hoverhang you rapidely realise that a good ventilation is critical. But blowing directly on the J-Head created to much cooling of the head itself.  
Following some advices I recived I went for insulation of the tip of the hotend.   
I went for blue silicone liquid seal (can be found in any automotive store) as it can whistand 250Â°C peak temperature.

• Apply the silicone generousely aroun the hot tip of the hotend, it should cover averythong the thermistor, the heating element with a layer of around 3mm thickness to insulate well.

  • Wait at least 24h to dry
  • With a cutter, cutaway just the extremetip where the extruded plastic comes out, making shure no part of the insulation silicone is lower than the tip.
    • That's it you now have a well insulated hot-end! Do not forget to recalibrate the PID parameters for the HotEnd because with the insulation these will be different you can use the following gcode "M303 S197 C8" as described in http://reprap.org/wiki/PID_Tuning
    I've included my config.h where the PID constants are stored.

remixed_from.author: chris
remixed_from.title: The FIBIAC - a simple electromechanical computer

title: The Turbo Entabulator - a 3D-printable, fully mechanical computer

description.text: This is is a simple, 3D-printable (caveat: It requires some springs, bearings, rubber bands, and nuts/bolts), fully-mechanical computer. It has 3, single-digit base-10 counters for memory, and processes a chain of 10-position punch cards. With the included program, it will compute the first few digits of the fibonacci sequence. It is effectively an entirely mechanical reimplementation my FIBIAC project (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22803) See it in action here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1lMTgYoIGvo And a full write-up here:http://www.chrisfenton.com/the-turbo-entabulator/ Take that Babbage!

This is more of a 3D-printable, mechanical computing construction kit, as replicating mine exactly might be difficult, as well as unnecessary.

  • I laser-cut a copy of 'pegboard.dxf' to give me a useful 12"x12" work area with holes cut every 0.5" to mount everything. Mounting things is left as an exercise for the reader (feel free to craft your own solution).

  • We need a way to process instructions! Print out one of these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:101077 and assemble it. This will let you drive 10 independent signals based on the cards you give it. Be sure to print out the 'conditional catch' and frame, rather than the 'unconditional' one.

  • Print out 2 copies of the jacquard_base_and_axle_holder, along with 10 copies of the jacquard_base_pulley. It is designed to use a 5/32" brass rod as the axle (same one used in the punch card reader 'griff', and available at hobby stores). Mount the punch card reader to the pegboard.

  • Print out 3 copies of this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:101068 - this will serve as the memory for the machine.

  • Secure all three counters to the pegboard so that they are parallel to one another, and have one hole of spacing between them. The zero_detect levers need to all be able to rotate the same shaft.

  • Print out 2 copies of the zd_shaft_frame (these support the zero_detect shaft on both ends, and allow it to rotate freely).

  • Print out two copies of the zd_drive_shaft, a copy of the zd_drive_shaft_end, and a copy of the zd_pulley_shaft_end.

  • Print out 2 copies of the zd_shaft_lever and zd_extended_lever.

  • Assemble the zero_detect drive shaft such that a lever is bolted to the shaft for each counter, and the lever extends above the zero detect arm of each counter. The levers should be in the same orientation such that when any counter is reading zero, the shaft gets rotated. The pulley_end of the zero detect shaft should be near the 'conditional catch frame' of the punch card reader.

  • Tie a string around the end of the conditional_catch lever arm. Through the creative use of pulleys, connect it to the pulley end of the zero detect shaft in such a way that when a zero_detect_arm rotates the shaft, the conditional catch lever gets lifted into position to rotate the card cylinder.

  • Print out like 2 dozen copies of the 'plastic pulley' (or use real pulleys if you can afford them and/or want your machine to work reliably). Print out at least 3 copies of the vertical_pulley_holder (to place beneath the zero-detect arms of the counters).

  • Route the strings from each hook to the ratchet pulling arms of all three counters, as well as the the very end of each zero detect arm on the counters. The layout I used (if you want to be instruction compatible with my Turbo Entabulator) is thus:
    • D=Decrement, I=Increment, Z=Zero_detect. R1=leftmost counter, R2=Rightmost counter.
    Left-to-right: {R1D, R3I, R1I, R3Z, R1Z,NOP,R2D, R3D, R2Z, R2I} Due to the size of the plastic pulleys I was using, and the layout of the registers, I had alternating strings coming from opposite sides of the card reader. The strings should go around the pulleys at the base of the card reader, before being attached to each hook with the M2 set-screws. Each hook should effectively pull straight-up on the string in order to maximize the 'throw'. I found that it works best to tie the string to the ratchet pulling arm, and then make it fairly taught on the setscrew when the hook is in its lowest position. I used embroidery floss to connect everything, which is generally a terrible idea, but I had it lying around. Something with a little bit of 'give' is nice, as the tolerances on the machine aren't great. Fiddling with the string tension is a big part of troubleshooting this thing.
  • Print out the four instruction cards and lace them together in order (I did this when they were 'in-place' on the cylinder, so that the spacing would be right). If you are facing the card reader with the crank-side closest to you, the embossed instruction numbers should be in the upper-left corner of each card.
    • An openscad model of the punch card would probably be great to use with the thingiverse 'app creator' thing, but I haven't had time for that yet. Thick cardstock should work fairly well (I think the cards I printed are 0.1" thick), I would think.
  • Turn the crank while humming the 'Powerhouse' song by Raymond Scott and marveling at your very own Turbo Entabulator - a 3D-printed, entirely mechanical computer!

comments.author: snellejelle99

comments.text:
I'm learning Java, so as a project, I decided to make an emulator of this "computer".
(As of this writing), it isn't complete, but it should be sometime soon.
As the "emulator" supports many 'memory banks', the punchcard system uses a boolean array as follows:
counter1 increment, counter1 decrement, counter1 check 0, counter2 increment, counter2 decrement, counter2 check 0... and so on and so forth.
If anyone is interested, it can be found here: https://github.com/dmelcer9/MechanicalComputerEmulator
comments.author: Dmelcer9

comments.text: I built a larger electromechanical version with the same basic architecture called the 'Numbotron': http://www.chrisfenton.com/the-numbotron/ - my website has a link to a simulator so you can play around with it. That one has 8 x 3-digit registers, and a drum that can hold 20 instructions. The main difference between the two, architecturally, is that the Numbotron will skip instructions if the 'check if zero' condition is true at the start of the instruction, whereas the turbo entabulator will still inc/dec all of the selected registers once if that's true. I haven't thought about how to do that entirely mechanically yet, but it lets you do branch predication, which enables much more complex programs for it (like finding prime numbers!). Check it out!

comments.author: 3DTOPO

comments.text: No problem! With each revolution of the hand-crank, a little punch card on the 'cylinder' (the rectangular box that has the 4 punch cards draped over it) selects a set of hooks that get lifted up. Each hook is tied to a string, so that when the hook gets lifted up, the string gets pulled on. Each one of the three counters has two strings connected to it. Pulling on one string increments the counter, pulling on the other string decrements it (if you tried to pull both at the same time, it would just jam up!).

remixed_from.author: szeedijk
remixed_from.title: Filament Guide Clip On with Bearing and Lock (extra strength)

description.text:
The idea is based on the Double Trapezoidal Z-Axis from Bondeus (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:327966), but I improved some things I needed to get it working. First of all there is a nut-holder (mutter.stl) - it's designed to fit an hexagonal trapezoidal nut (SW17L15, 17mm x 15mm). So it can be build into the brackets from Bondeus. Than there is a spool holder which is based on the one from cypax, but it's 100mm in length, so that ne Nunus-filament spools fit on them. Than there is the "stretcher" (spanner.stl) for using a 1210mm T5-Belt on Bondeus z-axis mod. It's based on the filament holder from szeedijk and the T5-18 Pulley from donboy. You need a 8mm screw, 3 nuts and a608zz ball bearings.
Put the ball bearing into the pulley and add it on the 8mm screw, add two of the nuts under it. Then push it trough the hole in the stretcher and secure it with the third nut. I'll add some pictures later.
Just print it the way you like - for the spanner add some support structures with your slicer. I used the option "Lines" in CuraEngine with a density of 15%.

title: The Ultimate 3mm and 4mm FlashForge Creator Pro Z-Axis Shims

description.text:
These are a remix of a remix, re-designed and perfectly matched to a Flashforge Creator Pro (built mid 2015).   
These shims are for use with 3mm or 4mm glass bed (or similar) upgrades.   
They are designed to perfectly fit around the two bolts, instead of leaving a gap, which will cause problems with the z-axis switch.  
Both designs are stamped with their respective shim heights should you have different height beds.  
Please upload photos if you make these! Thanks.

I've used no bed, and print these upside down as provided.  
Settings: 0.2mm, no support, 50% infill, 4 top and bottom layers.  
If this doesn't work for you, try flipping them over and printing. The reason I print the other side down is to prevent warping/bending of the piece, which can always be fixed afterwards by heating with a lighter or similar.  
Please upload photos if you make these! Thanks.

Further updates to this object may not be posted here. Have a hole in a panel, desk or bookshelf that needs to look nice with a hole grommet. But wait, the hole has to be big enough for a power cord and now the hole is too big. Well finish it off with a matching cover that let's the cord through and covers the hole. We use these to dress up holes in coroplast, acrylic, plywood, and other paneling so it looks professional and so that the cord or 3D printer filament doesn't snag. Don't want to download and install OpenSCAD, make your own with Customizer (on this page).

Edit the parameters to make the panel grommet as needed. The OpenSCAD code generates parts designed for each other. So that one once you set the parameters and then generate each part, the inside, outside and cover will fit together. The customizer and variables in the source are divided into four sections :

  • Panel

    • Panel thickness (mm)
    • Hole size (mm)

  • Grommet

    • Grommet (wall) thickness (mm)
      Note that this is the overall thickness of the grommet wall. The two parts will print half of the stated thickness - mated gives the full desired thickness.
    • Flange width (mm)
    • Flange thickness (mm)
    • Flange finish (chamfer or fillet)
    • Hide threads on outside part
      This shortens the inside part screw length by the flange thickness and narrows the outside part ID to the grommet ID. Don't do this if you have a very thin part (4 mm or less) since you won't have enough thread for the parts to firmly screw together.

  • Cover

    • Make hole (yes/ no)
    • Hole size (mm)
    • Plug length, auto limits to overall thickness (mm)
    • Plug wall thickness (mm)

  • Advanced
    Normally just go with the defaults but alter at your own risk. Changes here may make unprintable parts.

    • Thread pitch (mm)
    • Thread height to pitch (percent)
      A 50% setting would give a 2mm thread height on a 4mm pitch.
    • Resolution
      Line segments used to make a circle. Note the higher the number the longer the render will grind making your part. At "Insane" it may take longer than 30 minutes before customizer coughs up your part.
    • Chamfer angle (degrees)
      Any angle shallower than 45 degrees will probably not print well. Note that a narrow flange and shallow angles will produce unprintable parts.
    • Fillet edge area (percent)
      How much of the flange edge is consumed by the filleting curve.
    • Try to print at high resolution (both Z-step and circle resolution) but don't go insane. The higher resolutions will make for a better fit and finish. This is the thirteen reversion (v0.9.4) that has implemented the following fixes since the original version:
  • Length of inside part has been lengthened to correct length
  • Countersink on outside part has been removed for better finish
  • Hide exposed threads on outside part by narrowing flange hole to ID
  • Widen hole when hidden threads set to no
  • Fixed variable name to ensure correct inside part length
  • Added cover and fixed cover hole selection
  • Cosmetic spelling and variable name changes
  • Added inside fillet to improve join between cover plug and cap
  • Added flush cover
  • Added nudging to ensure cleaner object cuts
  • Renamed the Global section to General to work around Customizer bug
  • Fixed plug length to account for new blind in outside part
    • Seems the design is (mostly) stable. Please give feedback so the design can be improved. Keep checking back for updates if you've downloaded versus collected this part.

The middle_piece of the 3d printed shoulder rig can be quite hard to print on smaller printers like the Thing-o-Matic.

It's long cross-section may induce warping and it streches the limites of the build-platform. This one is more compact.

2 additional holes in the shape of an M5 nut in the camera_place may be required to use this as the front and back middle_piece to support that camera_plate with the compact middle_pieces as well. Blog post:

description.text: 3rd office phone holder has three components which must be assembled

This was made to try and get waterproof shapes when using PETG. It uses deliberately imperfect bridging underneath the object to create holes that allow any liquid that gets into the infill to leak out again.
This lets you test 'top layer' waterproofness, letting you choose number of top layers, extrusion width and other settings. Thin side walls test for leakage too. Item is nice and small(24mm dia, 37mm tall) for fast printing and should scale up well depending on how your printer can handle bridging. There is a 'curve' version that has a truncated sphere instead of a flat bottom to test top fill, curves and side walls, the full 'cup' in one go. Printed but untested. See instructions for notes on the effect of surface tension and print settings.

Print with a single bottom layer, 30-40% infill(Only tried with honeycomb) and as many top layers as you want to test. Don't print any smaller as surface tension becomes too big a factor, some prints looked like they worked fine using water, but I could actually see holes in the top layer. Water is strong stuff.
As it is, use try using a drop of dish-washing soap to break the surface tension(untested) or something instead of water(I've been using isopropnol as I have a big bottle of it). Put pieces of paper under each test to detect leaks.

title: Tool Holder for Type A Machines Series 1 Pro

description.text: This tool holder is designed to hold a set of exacto knives, scrapers, the essential glue stick and misc space for some smaller tools like wax carvers and files for picking support material.  It can hold a pen too.  It is designed to clip over the side panel that is about .17" thick. (Series 1 Pro)

It's important to position this as I show along the back vertical support of the machine so that the tools never lean toward the build plate and jam the plate.  It's a little snug for the exactos, but it seems to be fine.

comments.text: Looks like you have a Series 1 Pro.  It doesn't fit my regular Series 1, which appears to have a slightly thicker piece of plexiglass.  I think I need a 6 mm gap instead of a 4 mm gap.  Any chance you can upload the model?

author: jrpajaro

description.text: "It is called the Doomhammer because when its owner takes it into battle, it spells doom for the enemy. The last of the Doomhammer line will use it to bring first salvation and then doom to the orc people. Then it will pass into the hands of one who is not of the Blackrock clan, all will change again, and it will once again be used in the cause of justice." The legendary Doomhammer seems like a fitting last item to my series of Warcraft related PETG printables at least for now. Design was made combining features from many fan-art pictures as well as short cinematic in the game of Warcraft III. I tried to make it as easily printable as possible while still keeping the original look of the item. This was by far the most difficult of the three Warcraft items I have printed during the past weeks; not because of the printing though, but because of the post processing to get the "granite stone look" to certain parts and the gradient glow to the whole hammer head. Would have been easier with lighter blue PETG, but the one I ordered happened to be quite dark, so even with pure white LED's the glow is quite dim in comparison to the other two I made before. Another option would be to use colorless PETG and blue LED's. I think that'd have been easier as well. Hammer head printed from blue PETG. Rest of the parts PLA. Post processing and details done with Citadel miniature paints and melting the surface with a soldering iron to achieve the "chiseled stone" texture. Handle also has fake-leather strips wrapped around it.

Hammer head printed from blue PETG in two parts (cuts 1 & 2) with following settings: Layer height: 0.3mm
First layer height: 0.3mm
Perimeters: 2
Infill: 0%
No support/raft Rest of the parts printed from PLA with following settings: Layer height: 0.2mm
First layer height: 0.25mm
Perimeters: 2
Infill: 10%
No support/raft Assembly as follows:
  • Glue the hammer head parts 1 and 2 together.
  • Glue a piece of scrap metal with a positive wire attached to the bottom of the electronics holder, then push the holder to its place
  • Insert the negative wire through its channel inside the handle, leave plenty to work with on both ends. Insert the decorative ring to the handle just below the power switch place.
  • Insert LED's to the handle_base. I used 3 x pure white. Wire the leads through the channel and glue the LED's to their place.
  • Insert power switch to its place. Connect to the positive wire coming from the bottom of the electronics holder, and to the positive leads of LED's. Remember to use resistors in between if needed.
  • Connect the negative wire to the negative leads of LED's.
  • Attach the other end of the negative lead to a piece of scrap metal, preferably with a spring, and glue it to the handle_bottom with a bit of extra wire to allow removing the end cap when replacing batteries.
  • Assemble the handle by inserting 2 x AA batteries in and pushing the bottom cap to its place as well as the handle_base.
  • Push the assembled handle into its place in hammer_bottom, and the hammer_bottom to the main hammer head. Secure with glue.
  • Paint and decorate however you like. :)

Fallingwater or Kaufmann Residence is a house designed by architect Frank Lloyd Wright in 1935 in rural southwestern Pennsylvania, 43 miles (69 km) southeast of Pittsburgh.[3] The home was built partly over a waterfall on Bear Run in the Mill Run section of Stewart Township, Fayette County, Pennsylvania, in the Laurel Highlands of the Allegheny Mountains.
Hailed by Time shortly after its completion as Wright's "most beautiful job",[4] it is listed among Smithsonian's Life List of 28 places "to visit before you die."[5] It was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1966.[2] In 1991, members of the American Institute of Architects named the house the "best all-time work of American architecture" and in 2007, it was ranked twenty-ninth on the list of America's Favorite Architecture according to the AIA.

author: laniwan1

description.text:
I made this to mount my Elgae camera in the front of my ZMR250. It has been tilted 10 degrees, and recessed a bit, so the front element of the camera is shielded by the frame.   
The camera mounts snuggly, and is only held in place by friction from the bottom and top, this seems to work great for me, and ensures that the camera won't completely break, if a crash should make something hit it.
Printed with PLA at 200 micron at 190C and a 60C heated bed.

comments.text: Hi, why is the one standing on its side?  Any reason?
comments.author: knwest

comments.text: No, that's just the way Solid Works flips the part, you can just rotate it in your slicer :)
comments.author: knwest

comments.text: Thanks, this mount works perfect.  One small thing though.  Needs something to keep the cam from slipping through the back.  If you somehow enclosed the screw cutout it should keep it from slipping.  Thanks again.
comments.author: jacobtc

comments.text: Thanks, my intent was to only have the camera mounted by friction only, as to safe the camera if a big crash happens. Mine works great only by friction, is yours to loose?
comments.author: knwest

comments.text: Hi, yes. Just a little loose.  I was using it for a few weeks without issue and then a flip jarred it loose.  Added a small bit of foam to the screw groove and that snugged it up.  Not complaining, i love this mount!
comments.author: jacobtc

description.text:
Work in progress. I figured to try & develop a free positionable fan, to use on the Vertex K8400 printer, when producing very small parts. On occasion, these parts can be subject to excess heat, causing the build to melt & collapse a bit on itself. The intention is, when printing small parts, that I'd be able to position this fan into a suitable position on the print table - where the printer doesn't go during the build, obviously :-) - so it can help cool the small component. Please note:
  • A) It would be a good idea, to stick Anti-slip rubber to the fan housing on any side you'd want to position it on.
  • B) The electrical cord needs to be highly flexible.
    • The fan is a small 20mm 5V unit & is powered from a portable USB supply. The output is sufficient to put a small candle out, so with any luck this will help to tick the temperature of a small component a few degrees down. It is yet untested, though. I have a few multi-hour prints queued at the moment & have had this fan sitting around the desk for a few days now, unable to really test it on a small component. I figured to post it anyway & I'll update when I have tested and would need to see a need for changes.

title: Parametric PCB Box with Parametric Mounting Tabs

description.text:
You need a board holder that is X by Y mm and mounts to holes that are W by Z mm?  This is your script!
Typically when I need something like this, I am trying to match a board up with a mount that has a different hole spacing.  In this SCAD file, you specify the dimensions of the board, and the distance between the center of the mounting holes.  The script and your 3d printer does the rest.
Open the file, specify the dimensions at the top.  Go to the box method and make sure you un-comment or comment the tabs as appropriate if you want less than 4 tabs.

description.text:
Schoen I6 surface modeled in Rhino V5 and thickened in MeshLab. Approximate dimensions 65mm cubed, with a 1.4mm wall. Visit this link to find out more: http://facstaff.susqu.edu/brakke/evolver/examples/periodic/periodic.html#I6 The surface creates a checkerboard-like pattern on the end faces, resulting in some serious overhangs. In order to print without generating support material, I modeled support faces that can be easily removed with an X-acto blade. Also, check out the write-up on my website!
http://moczys.com/2015/09/12/minimal-surfaces/

Modeled in rhino using approximate surfacing techniques. Thickened mesh created in Meshlab. The model with the suffix "_support" will print without needing to generate support material in your slicing program. Printed at 0.25mm layer thickness. Take a look at this article for the modeling process: http://moczys.com/2015/04/06/gyroid-modeling-and-3d-printing/
